conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source, creating a region of darkness behind the object.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position and distance of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves downward, it gets closer to the objects and the surface (ground).
The closer the light source is to the object, the larger the shadow becomes because the angle of light rays hitting the object becomes more acute, causing the shadow to spread out more.
As the light source moves downward, the direction of the light rays changes, causing the shadows to shift closer to the objects.
The shadows will appear directly beneath the objects if the light source is directly above, or they will shift slightly depending on the new angle of the light.
The shadows will become larger because the light rays diverge more when the light source is closer to the objects.
The increased divergence causes the shadow edges to extend further out on the ground.
Shadow A (Milkshake) will move closer to the base of the milkshake and increase in size, becoming wider and possibly more elongated depending on the angle.
Shadow B (Typewriter) will shift closer to the typewriter and increase in size, potentially becoming more distorted due to the complex shape of the typewriter.
Shadow C (Sphere) will move closer to the sphere and become larger. Since the sphere is round, the shadow will remain circular but increase in diameter.
Shadow D (Cone) will shift closer to the cone and increase in size. The shadow will maintain its general shape but will be larger and may become more elongated.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move closer to their respective objects.
All shadows will increase in size due to the decreased distance between the light source and the objects.
When the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to their respective objects and increase in size.
